SENT.plain: Reversible posterior leucoencephalopathy and cerebral venous thrombosis share many symptoms
Both of them may lead to coma, and cause epilepsy or focal neurological signs
Moreover, diffuse leucoencephalopathy can be observed in both cases
Cerebral venous thrombosis needs anticoagulation which is not a riskless treatment

We describe a case of reversible posterior leucoencephalopathy in an hypertensed, seventy-year old man, presenting with a left lateral sinus hypoplasia whose clinical history and paramedical results first suggested a cerebral veinous thrombosis
Our case shows the misleadings a congenital vascular asymmetry can induce when confronted with a subacute coma
